{"step_by_step_thinking": "Aspirin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that works by reducing substances in the body that cause pain, fever, and inflammation. It does not act directly on a specific part of the brain, but rather it inhibits the production of prostaglandins, substances that the body releases in response to illness and injury. Prostaglandins cause pain and swelling, or inflammation. They are made in the brain, spinal cord, and other parts of the body. Therefore, none of the options provided are correct.", "answer_choice": "None of the above"}
